From, Major-General J.H.K*Stewart, C.B., D.S.O., Political Resident, Aden. To, His Majesty’s Secretary of State for the Colonies, London. Sir, I have the honour to invite a reference to my telegram No.54 of 22nd May 1926, reporting that the Italians intended appointing a Consular Officer at Hodeidah. 2* The question arises whether it would not be advisable, provided the Imam agrees, to have a British Consular Officer at the same town. Our present agent there, though sometimes referred to in your despatches as Political Officer (e.g.your No.29 of 1st May 1926) is merely an Arabic Clerk, (originally 2nd Clerk in the British Consulate at Hodeidah,) with no knowledge of English, and not altogether satisfactory. The only reason why I have not tried to get a substitute for him is that the question of his retention is about to be considered shortly (your telegram of 1st April 1926) and in the meantime he enables us to keep a watch on events and a lien on Hodeidah with reference to any other representative we may wish to send there. 3. There was a British Vice-Consul at Hodeidah for many years before the War, so the appointment of one now would be no new departure. From a commercial point ofof view the port is of importance; before the War its annual trade exceeded £1,000,000, a very large proportion of which was British and British Indian (vide Consular Report No.4608 of 1910 on Hodeidah sent unfler your despatch No.21 of 17th March 1926). There is no need to emphasise the political importance of Hodeidah as the door of the Yemen opening on the outside world. 4. If a Consular Officer were appointed at Hodeidah, presumably he would be under the general control of this Residency which is the British Agency most nearly in touch with the Yemen. I have the honour to be, Sir, Your most obedient servant, (Signed) J.H-K. Calliope would visit some of the Southern Red Sea Ports on the Arabian coast at the beginning of January I consider it advisable in view of present political situation that a civil officer should accompany her. As I could not spare any political officer from Aden I have sent Captain Wickham Civil Administrator of Kamaran in H.M.S. Clematis which was going to Malta and instructed him to meet H.M.S. titleInfo.title: Coll 6/28 'Hodeidah: Suggested Appointment of a British Consul at. Political control of Hodeidah Mission.'

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the rear to the front of the file.

Foliation: the foliation sequence commences at the front cover with 1 and terminates at the inside back cover with 30; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio.

mods.abstract: This file consists of copies of Foreign Office and Colonial Office correspondence regarding the proposed appointment of a British Consul at Hodeidah [Al Ḩudaydah], Yemen.The correspondence discusses a proposal, put forward by the Political Resident at Aden, Major-General John Henry Keith Stewart, for the Civil Administrator at Kamaran, Captain Wickham (whose post is under Government of India control), to be appointed Political Officer of the Southern Red Sea Coast, with the existing Hodeidah mission placed under his control. In the correspondence Stewart suggests that such an appointment would be preferable to the present arrangement, which requires the person currently in charge of the office of Political Officer at Hodeidah, namely Stewart's First Assistant Resident in Aden, to engage in 'avoidable correspondence' with the Political Clerk at Hodeidah, since he is not able to leave his duties in Aden.The principal correspondents are the Political Resident at Aden, the Secretary of State for the Colonies (Leopold Stennett Amery), and various officials of the Colonial Office and Foreign Office.The file includes a divider which gives a list of correspondence references contained in the file by year. This is placed at the back of the correspondence.
